title: European Law : politics in the EU
description:
####This course will give an overview of several fields of competences of the European Union. 
It will aim at offering a better comprehension of the concrete actions carried out by the EU.
After describing the political finality and the specificity of the original community project, it will analyze the different scope of competencies of the EU, illustrating the hybrid nature of the EU, as amix of supranational and intergovernmental organization.

The selected topics will highlight the three different types of competences of the EU (exclusive/shared/supporting competences): internal market; economic and monetary union; agriculture; energy; education.

By covering economic as well as political tasks of the EU, the course will reexamine the role and the results of the method of European integration commonly known as **"spillover effect"** or **"functionalism"**. 
Emphasis will be put on current developments. Critical discussion will be encouraged.

**The course will take place from the 1st March to 22nd May 2023**

**Workload: 66 hours**

**Final assessment: online test**

description: This course will explore the history of various European empires, starting with a study of the multi-faceted notion of ‚Äòempire‚Äô, as will be first illustrated by the complex reality and history of the Holy Roman Empire (962-1806). It will then look at how Portugal, Spain, Britain and Italy took control of and ruled overseas territories, describe how European domination was resisted and ended, and explain the traces left by colonization and imperialism in the contemporary world. Students will be presented with historical texts and images, and will have to establish logical links between the various cases so as to try and make sense of the different European imperial experiencesbeyond their apparent heterogeneity.

title: Understanding Regulation, Theory and Practice
description:
After the last economic crisis, calls for more ‚Äúregulation‚Äù, especially in financial markets, were  widespread both at the national and the international level. To avoid the occurrence of such crisis or to reduce its magnitude, it is argued that more regulations are required. Regulations are indeed  tools to shape economic systems. As such, they have tremendous impacts on economic growth and  the well-being of population. 
If the content of regulations is to be known when strategies are considered, it is especially crucial  for both lawyers and policy makers to understand the foundations of these regulations. For lawyers,  it helps to develop innovative interpretations and powerful arguments; for policy makers to  understand the consequences and the inherent limits of their actions while also providing tools to  apprehend and criticize existing regulations.  
This course will inquire into the reasons for regulations, the options that are available when a  regulation is considered, their limits and the strategies to deal with them. 
The purpose of this course is to provide students with the necessary tools to develop, question and  criticize regulations.

title: Luxury: social psychological approaches for professionals
description: The main objective is to make students familiar with a psychosocial perspective on luxury. The  course addresses the psychosocial processes that underlie interactions in professional  contexts in luxury businesses (hotels, restaurants, resorts, stores, etc.). On the one hand, the  course provides a psychosocial analysis and contextualisation of the social thinking and  behaviour of luxury customers, considering the contemporary specificities of interactional  situations between luxury professionals and customers (for example, environmental  concerns). On the other hand, the course provides students with knowledge and tools to  better understand the functioning of small groups (work teams, person in the group, etc.)  in the luxury business. In addition, the course contributes to the development of students‚Äô  soft skills, such as active listening, leadership, conflict management, group work, cross cultural interactional skills.

title: British Literature and Culture I
description: The lecture course for students in the BA English Studies programme offers an overview of British literature and culture from the medieval period to the end of the eighteenth century. Its aim is to  provide basic information about the socio-cultural environment in which major cultural and literary events took place. The lecture course is held by three instructors, depending on the topic at hand. It relies on primary readings and highly recommended reference materials, which are made available online for students. General objectives: students completing this survey course will have an overview of British literary history from the Middle Ages to the end of the eighteenth century. They will improve their analytic skills through the exploration of connections between literary texts and their different historical, social and cultural contexts, They will be better equipped for the analysis of literary texts in a variety of genres and will learn about the emergence and early history of literary genres popular today, They will be able to make a connection between current cultural, media, and literary events and trends, and their literary-historical precedents. Short-term  achievements: by attending the lecture course, students will gain information on the best canonical writers, their works, and the historical and cultural contexts of the discussed literary periods. Long-term achievements: the course is an essential part of the English Studies BA programme.  \nCo-teachers: Filip Krajnik, Csaba Maczelka\nTimetable: Wednesday: 16:00

title: European Criminal Law (EUCRIM)
description:
Our pedagogical team from the Masaryk University,theUniversity of Potsdam, the University of Cagliariand the University of P√©cs aims to create a course which provides thorough  understanding  of  the  topic  of European criminal law ‚Äìone of the fastest developing EU policies. The topic is quite extensive: it involves the traditional issue of transnational organised crimeand how to tackle it (as such legal instruments of operative cooperation  of  law  enforcement  and  judicial  authorities  of  EU  Member  Statesand  the  harmonisation  of substantive criminal lawshall be presentedas indispensable toolsin EU criminal law). However,the speedy technological advancement created issues that did not exist in the past ‚Äìor at least not to such an extent as today. As such the course also involves an in-depth analysis of cybercrime and EU criminal law designed to tackle  it  (among  others  the  European Production  Order  and  the  European  Preservation  Order  will  be introduced in the course). Last,but not least the protection of fundamental rights must be emphasised since EU criminal law is a policy area which greatly affects the freedom of EU citizens (in this context the principle of mutual trust, the ne bis in idem principleand the practice of the Court of Justice of the European Union shall be presented).
Timetable: From 10 February - on Thursdays at 14:00
